elements.content: The metal-directed self-assembly of dimethyltin(IV) and homophthalate provided tetranuclear bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) secondary building units (SBUs), which in the solid state are linked to a three-dimensional honeycomb architecture having hexameric channels with diameters of 5.2 Å. These channels are occupied by water clusters of composition {H2O} x (with x = 12−14) that have adamantane-type structures as they are found in the cubic ice modification.
elements.clean_text: The metal-directed self-assembly of dimethyltin(IV) and homophthalate provided tetranuclear bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) secondary building units (SBUs), which in the solid state are linked to a three-dimensional honeycomb architecture having hexameric channels with diameters of 5.2 Å. These channels are occupied by water clusters of composition {H2O} x  (with x = 12-14) that have adamantane-type structures as they are found in the cubic ice modification.

elements.content: Metal-directed self-assembly of dimethyltin(IV) and homophthalate provided tetranuclear bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) secondary building units (SBUs), which in the solid state are linked to a three-dimensional honeycomb architecture having hexameric channels that are occupied by water clusters of composition {H2O} x (with x = 12−14).
elements.clean_text: Metal-directed self-assembly of dimethyltin(IV) and homophthalate provided tetranuclear bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) secondary building units (SBUs), which in the solid state are linked to a three-dimensional honeycomb architecture having hexameric channels that are occupied by water clusters of composition {H2O} x  (with x = 12-14).

elements.content: Supramolecular synthesis consists of the combination of properly designed building blocks to functional architectures through noncovalent interactions such as coordinative bonds, hydrogen bonds, or π···π interactions, and has been extensively explored for the preparation of macrocyclic, cage-like, and infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) structures. Metal−organic systems can be assembled either from single-metal ion nodes or from more complex building units containing two or more metal centers. Such secondary building units (SBUs) are frequently employed for the generation of non-interpenetrating porous materials having high thermal stability, which makes them attractive targets for applications related to separation, storage, transport, and catalysis.
elements.clean_text: Supramolecular synthesis consists of the combination of properly designed building blocks to functional architectures through noncovalent interactions such as coordinative bonds, hydrogen bonds, or π⋅⋅⋅π interactions, and has been extensively explored for the preparation of macrocyclic, cage-like, and infinite one-, two-, and three-dimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) structures. Metal-organic systems can be assembled either from single-metal ion nodes or from more complex building units containing two or more metal centers. Such secondary building units (SBUs) are frequently employed for the generation of non-interpenetrating porous materials having high thermal stability, which makes them attractive targets for applications related to separation, storage, transport, and catalysis.

elements.content: Among the main group elements that have received the most attention for metal-directed self-assembly is tin. Thereby, organometallic tin derivatives are particularly interesting since the organic groups attached to the tin atoms allow the modification of the structure and functionality of the resulting supramolecular network. So far, systems derived from tin SBUs are almost unexplored, albeit several research groups have shown previously that dimeric dicarboxylatotetraorganodistannoxanes are proper for the generation of macrocycles, cryptands, and 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers. Making a further contribution to this field, herein we describe the first porous 3D coordination polymer assembled from a bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) SBU and a dicarboxylate linker (homophthalate).
elements.clean_text: Among the main group elements that have received the most attention for metal-directed self-assembly is tin. Thereby, organometallic tin derivatives are particularly interesting since the organic groups attached to the tin atoms allow the modification of the structure and functionality of the resulting supramolecular network. So far, systems derived from tin SBUs are almost unexplored, albeit several research groups have shown previously that dimeric dicarboxylatotetraorganodistannoxanes are proper for the generation of macrocycles, cryptands, and 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers. Making a further contribution to this field, herein we describe the first porous 3D coordination polymer assembled from a bis(tetraorganodistannoxane) SBU and a dicarboxylate linker (homophthalate).

elements.content: The title compound was prepared at room temperature from a 1:1 stoichiometric mixture of dimethyltin dichloride and the dipotassium salt of hphtH2 in a 9:1 solvent mixture of methanol and water (Scheme ). The product was obtained as a microcrystalline solid at a yield of 34% and has been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, and single-crystal X-ray crystallography. These analyses showed that the title compound is a 3D coordination polymer of the composition {[(Me2SnOSnMe2)(μ3-hpht)]2·4.33H2O} n .
elements.clean_text: The title compound was prepared at room temperature from a 1:1 stoichiometric mixture of dimethyltin dichloride and the dipotassium salt of hphtH2 in a 9:1 solvent mixture of methanol and water (Scheme ). The product was obtained as a microcrystalline solid at a yield of 34% and has been characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetric (TG) analysis, and single-crystal X-ray crystallography. These analyses showed that the title compound is a 3D coordination polymer of the composition {[(Me2SnOSnMe2)(μ3-hpht)]2⋅4.33H2O} n .

elements.content: The IR data show that both carboxylate groups are coordinated to the tin metal centers. First, because there are no bands in the region for stretching and deformation vibrations of hydroxyl groups, which are present in the starting material (νO−H = 2624 and 2538 cm−1; δO−H = 966 cm−1), and, second, because the spectrum shows strong bands in the region typical for anisobidentate or bridging carboxylate groups (νas(OCO) = 1590 and 1551 cm−1; νs(OCO) = 1395 and 1365 cm−1). Moreover, a broad absorption band at 3446 cm−1 indicates the presence of uncoordinated water.
elements.clean_text: The IR data show that both carboxylate groups are coordinated to the tin metal centers. First, because there are no bands in the region for stretching and deformation vibrations of hydroxyl groups, which are present in the starting material (νO-H = 2624 and 2538 cm-1; δO-H = 966 cm-1), and, second, because the spectrum shows strong bands in the region typical for anisobidentate or bridging carboxylate groups (νas(OCO) = 1590 and 1551 cm-1; νs(OCO) = 1395 and 1365 cm-1). Moreover, a broad absorption band at 3446 cm-1 indicates the presence of uncoordinated water.

elements.content: The crystalline material of the title compound has an uncommon spherical shape similar to that described by Clearfield and co-workers for Sn(O3PC6H5)2, and has been therefore examined by SEM. Figure shows a representative globule with a diameter of 210 μm (Figure , left panel) together with a 100-fold amplification of the surface (Figure , right panel). The close-view allows one to distinguish small, fused microcrystallites. Such a fusion seems to be a reasonable phenomenon for 3D coordination polymers having flexible spacer groups, thus allowing for bonding between the crystal lattices of the corresponding microcrystallites (vide infra).
elements.clean_text: The crystalline material of the title compound has an uncommon spherical shape similar to that described by Clearfield and co-workers for Sn(O3PC6H5)2, and has been therefore examined by SEM. Figure  shows a representative globule with a diameter of 210 μm (Figure , left panel) together with a 100-fold amplification of the surface (Figure , right panel). The close-view allows one to distinguish small, fused microcrystallites. Such a fusion seems to be a reasonable phenomenon for 3D coordination polymers having flexible spacer groups, thus allowing for bonding between the crystal lattices of the corresponding microcrystallites (vide infra).

elements.content: SEM images of the spherical shaped microcrystalline material of the title compound: (left) globule with a diameter of 210 μm and (right) close view of the surface (100-fold amplification).
elements.clean_text: 1  SEM images of the spherical shaped microcrystalline material of the title compound: (left) globule with a diameter of 210 μm and (right) close view of the surface (100-fold amplification).

elements.content: Since part of the crystalline material contained monocrystalline blocks of larger size, it was possible to separate a single-crystal that could be examined by X-ray diffraction analysis. This experiment revealed that the microcrystalline blocks consist of a 3D coordination polymer that crystallized in the trigonal spacegroup R3̅. Figure shows the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBU from which the infinite solid-state structure is constructed. This fragment has inversion symmetry and, therefore, labels are given only for the asymmetric unit. The central tetranuclear bis(distannoxane) fragment, {[Me2Sn(μ3-O)SnMe2]2}, which is connected through Sn−O bonds with distances ranging from 2.024(2) to 2.158(2) Å, is coordinated to the carboxylate groups of four different hpht ligands. Of these, the CPh-COO functions act as syn−syn isobidentate bridges between neighboring tin atoms (Sn1−O3 = 2.299(2) Å; Sn2−O4 = 2.236(2) Å), whereas the CH2COO functions are coordinated only to one tin atom in an anisobidentate coordination mode (Sn1−O1 = 2.170(2) Å; Sn1···O2 = 2.757(2) Å). Since there is an additional weak secondary interaction between O1 and Sn2′ (3.008(2) Å), both tin atoms have similar distorted monocapped trigonal-bipyramidal {C2SnO4} coordination geometries, in which the methyl groups occupy equatorial positions. The C−Sn−C bond angles are 137.73(14) and 145.12(15)°, and agree well with those reported for bis(tetraorganodistannoxanes) derived from monocarboxylate ligands. The influence of the secondary O···Sn interactions (O2···Sn1 and O1···Sn2′) can be seen also from the O−Sn−O bond angles formed between the oxygen atoms located in axial positions (O1−Sn1−O3 = 172.26(9)°; O4−Sn2−O5′ = 164.42(9)°).
elements.clean_text: Since part of the crystalline material contained monocrystalline blocks of larger size, it was possible to separate a single-crystal that could be examined by X-ray diffraction analysis. This experiment revealed that the microcrystalline blocks consist of a 3D coordination polymer that crystallized in the trigonal spacegroup R3̅. Figure  shows the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBU from which the infinite solid-state structure is constructed. This fragment has inversion symmetry and, therefore, labels are given only for the asymmetric unit. The central tetranuclear bis(distannoxane) fragment, {[Me2Sn(μ3-O)SnMe2]2}, which is connected through Sn-O bonds with distances ranging from 2.024(2) to 2.158(2) Å, is coordinated to the carboxylate groups of four different hpht ligands. Of these, the CPh-COO functions act as syn-syn isobidentate bridges between neighboring tin atoms (Sn1-O3 = 2.299(2) Å; Sn2-O4 = 2.236(2) Å), whereas the CH2COO functions are coordinated only to one tin atom in an anisobidentate coordination mode (Sn1-O1 = 2.170(2) Å; Sn1⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.757(2) Å). Since there is an additional weak secondary interaction between O1 and Sn2' (3.008(2) Å), both tin atoms have similar distorted monocapped trigonal-bipyramidal {C2SnO4} coordination geometries, in which the methyl groups occupy equatorial positions. The C-Sn-C bond angles are 137.73(14) and 145.12(15)°, and agree well with those reported for bis(tetraorganodistannoxanes) derived from monocarboxylate ligands. The influence of the secondary O⋅⋅⋅Sn interactions (O2⋅⋅⋅Sn1 and O1⋅⋅⋅Sn2') can be seen also from the O-Sn-O bond angles formed between the oxygen atoms located in axial positions (O1-Sn1-O3 = 172.26(9)°; O4-Sn2-O5' = 164.42(9)°).

elements.content: Fragment of the 3D coordination polymer showing the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBUs and their linkage to the organic dicarboxylate bridges (hpht). Ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 2  Fragment of the 3D coordination polymer showing the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBUs and their linkage to the organic dicarboxylate bridges (hpht). Ellipsoids are shown at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: In the crystal lattice, six of the above-described SBUs form unique 48-membered macrocyclic rings of the composition {[C5O2Sn]6} (Figure ), which are structurally somewhat related to a series of previously reported hexanuclear organotin macrocycles derived from 3-thiopropionic acid, thiosalicylic acid, and 3,5-di-iso-propylsalicylic acid. The distance between neighboring tin atoms is 6.25 Å, and the trannsannular Sn···Sn distance is 12.42 Å. Within the macrocyclic ring, the tin atoms adopt a chairlike conformation, thus orienting the SBUs alternately above and below the ring plane. Since each SBU participates in the formation of two hexanuclear tin macrocycles, ondulated honeycomb-type layers emerge (Figure b), which are further interconnected in an ABAB... fashion to an overall 3D polymer (Figure c,d). To the best of our knowledge, this is only the second 3D distannoxane-based framework. The first has been assembled recently under hydrothermal conditions by Ma and co-workers from chiral cis-(1R,3S)-(+)-camphoric acid and trimethyltin chloride.
elements.clean_text: In the crystal lattice, six of the above-described SBUs form unique 48-membered macrocyclic rings of the composition {[C5O2Sn]6} (Figure ), which are structurally somewhat related to a series of previously reported hexanuclear organotin macrocycles derived from 3-thiopropionic acid, thiosalicylic acid, and 3,5-di-iso-propylsalicylic acid. The distance between neighboring tin atoms is 6.25 Å, and the trannsannular Sn⋅⋅⋅Sn distance is 12.42 Å. Within the macrocyclic ring, the tin atoms adopt a chairlike conformation, thus orienting the SBUs alternately above and below the ring plane. Since each SBU participates in the formation of two hexanuclear tin macrocycles, ondulated honeycomb-type layers emerge (Figure b), which are further interconnected in an ABAB... fashion to an overall 3D polymer (Figure c,d). To the best of our knowledge, this is only the second 3D distannoxane-based framework. The first has been assembled recently under hydrothermal conditions by Ma and co-workers from chiral cis-(1R,3S)-(+)-camphoric acid and trimethyltin chloride.

elements.content: Fragments of the 3D coordination polymer showing: (a) the macrocyclic hexanuclear rings formed from the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBUs shown in Figure , (b) the ondulated honeycomb-type 2D layer, and (c, d) the interconnection of the 2D layers in an ABAB... fashion to give an overall 3D coordination polymer (top and lateral view). Ellipsoids in (a) are shown at the 50% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 3  Fragments of the 3D coordination polymer showing: (a) the macrocyclic hexanuclear rings formed from the bis(tetramethyldistannoxane) SBUs shown in Figure , (b) the ondulated honeycomb-type 2D layer, and (c, d) the interconnection of the 2D layers in an ABAB... fashion to give an overall 3D coordination polymer (top and lateral view). Ellipsoids in (a) are shown at the 50% probability level.

elements.content: It can be assumed that the semirigid nature of the ligand plays an important role in the assembly of this 3D stucture. Since the CH2COO group can adopt a whole range of different spatial orientations with respect to the rigid CPhCOO group, hpht2− seems to be an ideal ligand for the creation of supramolecular structures, which require nonstandard bonding angles (i.e., 60, 90, 109, 120, and 180 °) between the metal-coordinating functions. A revision of the CSD showed that there are only few entries for metal−organic assemblies derived from hphtH2 so far. The ligand flexibility might be also responsible for the spherical organization of the microcrystalline material, since free-rotating pendant carboxylate groups at the crystal surface can cause defects during the crystallization process and allow for an interconnection of microcrystallites. The controlled linkage of microcrystallites to macroscopic entities deserves further exploration, since it might allow for the generation of materials with interesting physical and chemical properties.
elements.clean_text: It can be assumed that the semirigid nature of the ligand plays an important role in the assembly of this 3D stucture. Since the CH2COO group can adopt a whole range of different spatial orientations with respect to the rigid CPhCOO group, hpht2- seems to be an ideal ligand for the creation of supramolecular structures, which require nonstandard bonding angles (i.e., 60, 90, 109, 120, and 180 °) between the metal-coordinating functions. A revision of the CSD showed that there are only few entries for metal-organic assemblies derived from hphtH2 so far. The ligand flexibility might be also responsible for the spherical organization of the microcrystalline material, since free-rotating pendant carboxylate groups at the crystal surface can cause defects during the crystallization process and allow for an interconnection of microcrystallites. The controlled linkage of microcrystallites to macroscopic entities deserves further exploration, since it might allow for the generation of materials with interesting physical and chemical properties.

elements.content: The channels formed along axis c have diameters of approximately 5.2 Å, and it is important to note that the inner walls are lined with oxygen atoms (Figure ). It is therefore not surprising to find that the pores are occupied by water molecules, which form clusters having the composition {H2O}12, {H2O}13, and {H2O}14 (Figure ). All three arrangements are fragments of the cubic ice modification, which at standard pressure is only stable at temperatures below −120 °C. While the {H2O}12 cluster can be described as a six-membered chair having six pendant water molecules in the axial positions, the {H2O}13 and {H2O}14 cages are extended adamantane-type arrangements of the water molecules. It should be noticed that there are relatively few structural reports on adamantane-type water clusters so far.
elements.clean_text: The channels formed along axis c have diameters of approximately 5.2 Å, and it is important to note that the inner walls are lined with oxygen atoms (Figure ). It is therefore not surprising to find that the pores are occupied by water molecules, which form clusters having the composition {H2O}12, {H2O}13, and {H2O}14 (Figure ). All three arrangements are fragments of the cubic ice modification, which at standard pressure is only stable at temperatures below -120 °C. While the {H2O}12 cluster can be described as a six-membered chair having six pendant water molecules in the axial positions, the {H2O}13 and {H2O}14 cages are extended adamantane-type arrangements of the water molecules. It should be noticed that there are relatively few structural reports on adamantane-type water clusters so far.

elements.clean_text: 4  Spacefilling model of the title compound showing the channels formed along axis c.

elements.content: {H2O} x clusters (x = 12−14) are located within the channels shown in Figure . Ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level.
elements.clean_text: 5  {H2O} x  clusters (x = 12-14) are located within the channels shown in Figure . Ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level.

elements.content: Within the {H2O} x clusters, the O···O distances vary from 2.84 to 2.89 Å, and are similar to those found for bulk liquid water (2.85 Å) and other previously reported water clusters. The OW···OW···OW bond angles vary from 98.2 to 120.4° and are significantly different from the tetrahedral angle found in ice I h and I c , thus indicating that the adamantane-type clusters are distorted.
elements.clean_text: Within the {H2O} x  clusters, the O⋅⋅⋅O distances vary from 2.84 to 2.89 Å, and are similar to those found for bulk liquid water (2.85 Å) and other previously reported water clusters. The OW⋅⋅⋅OW⋅⋅⋅OW bond angles vary from 98.2 to 120.4° and are significantly different from the tetrahedral angle found in ice I  h  and I  c , thus indicating that the adamantane-type clusters are distorted.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the thermal stability of the title compound, a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. After an initial weight loss of approximately 3.8% within the temperature range of 40−100 °C, there was no further substantial weight change until a temperature of 220 °C, at which decomposition began. This result indicates that only a partial loss of the water molecules located within the porous channels occurred (calculated for 2.33 of the 4.33 equiv of water molecules per SBU: 3.9%). This can be probably attributed to the fact that the remaining 2 equiv of water molecules are retained through strong hydrogen-bonding interactions and/or O···Sn coordination bonds within the diorganotin carboxylate framework. That penta- and hexacoordinated diorganotin dicarboxylates can enhance their coordination number through coordination to water molecules has been shown previously. In order to examine if the crystal lattice does resist the partial elimination of guest molecules without collapsing, we heated part of the crystalline material for 1 h at 180 °C under a vacuum (approximately 10−2 Torr). The experiment showed that this thermal treatment did not destroy the crystallinity of the material, since the unit cell of the crystals remained unchanged (several crystals were examined).
elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the thermal stability of the title compound, a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. After an initial weight loss of approximately 3.8% within the temperature range of 40-100 °C, there was no further substantial weight change until a temperature of 220 °C, at which decomposition began. This result indicates that only a partial loss of the water molecules located within the porous channels occurred (calculated for 2.33 of the 4.33 equiv of water molecules per SBU: 3.9%). This can be probably attributed to the fact that the remaining 2 equiv of water molecules are retained through strong hydrogen-bonding interactions and/or O⋅⋅⋅Sn coordination bonds within the diorganotin carboxylate framework. That penta- and hexacoordinated diorganotin dicarboxylates can enhance their coordination number through coordination to water molecules has been shown previously. In order to examine if the crystal lattice does resist the partial elimination of guest molecules without collapsing, we heated part of the crystalline material for 1 h at 180 °C under a vacuum (approximately 10-2 Torr). The experiment showed that this thermal treatment did not destroy the crystallinity of the material, since the unit cell of the crystals remained unchanged (several crystals were examined).

elements.content: In conclusion, this contribution shows that organotin-containing SBUs are suitable for the generation of porous materials. Since three parameters can be varied for coordination polymers formed from organotin clusters, (i) the metal-coordinating function (carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphonate, etc.), (ii) the organic spacer between the metal-coordinating carboxylate groups, and (iii) the organic groups attached to the tin atoms, such architectures might have advantages over other systems, for example, with respect to pore-size tuning or the generation of chiral cavities.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, this contribution shows that organotin-containing SBUs are suitable for the generation of porous materials. Since three parameters can be varied for coordination polymers formed from organotin clusters, (i) the metal-coordinating function (carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphonate, etc.), (ii) the organic spacer between the metal-coordinating carboxylate groups, and (iii) the organic groups attached to the tin atoms, such architectures might have advantages over other systems, for example, with respect to pore-size tuning or the generation of chiral cavities.

For the preparation of compound 1, homophthalic acid (0.077 g, 0.43 mmol) and 2 equiv of potassium hydroxide (0.048 g, 0.85 mmol) were dissolved in a 9:1 mixture of methanol and water (15 mL), whereupon 1 equiv of dimethyltin dichloride (0.094 g, 0.43 mmol) dissolved in methanol (5 mL) was added. A white microcrystalline precipitate formed that was insoluble in common organic solvents. Yield: 0.039 g (34%). Mp >220 °C (dec.). IR (KBr): ν̃ = 3436 (m), 3072 (w), 3004 (w), 2919 (w), 1590 νas(OCO) (s), 1551 νas(OCO) (s), 1395 νs(OCO) (s), 1365 νs(OCO) (s), 1195 (w), 1163 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 937 (w), 802 (m), 730 (m), 641 (s), 581 (m), 497 (m), 447 (w) cm−1. C13H18O5Sn2·2.17H2O (530.69): calcd. C 29.42, H 4.24; found C 29.54, H 4.13

elements.content: It should be noticed that different isomers of bis(tetraorganodistannoxanes) are known, which differ from each other by the number of carboxylate groups acting as syn−syn bidentate bridges between the tetranuclear Sn4O2 core. For reviews see:

elements.content:
Cambridge Structural Database, Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, version 5.29, November 2007, Cambridge, UK

The channels are occupied by three crystallographically independent water molecules, of which one (O33) is located at the 3̅-symmetry axis. Since the O33 water molecules are disordered furthermore over two positions (occ = 0.167), three water clusters can be formulated: {H2O}12, {H2O}13, and {H2O}14. Their distribution within the channels is probably statistical

For the preparation of compound 1, homophthalic acid (0.077 g, 0.43 mmol) and 2 equiv of potassium hydroxide (0.048 g, 0.85 mmol) were dissolved in a 9:1 mixture of methanol and water (15 mL), whereupon 1 equiv of dimethyltin dichloride (0.094 g, 0.43 mmol) dissolved in methanol (5 mL) was added. A white microcrystalline precipitate formed that was insoluble in common organic solvents. Yield: 0.039 g (34%). Mp >220 °C (dec.). IR (KBr): ν̃ = 3436 (m), 3072 (w), 3004 (w), 2919 (w), 1590 νas(OCO) (s), 1551 νas(OCO) (s), 1395 νs(OCO) (s), 1365 νs(OCO) (s), 1195 (w), 1163 (w), 1090 (w), 1047 (w), 937 (w), 802 (m), 730 (m), 641 (s), 581 (m), 497 (m), 447 (w) cm-1. C13H18O5Sn2⋅2.17H2O (530.69): calcd. C 29.42, H 4.24; found C 29.54, H 4.13

cln_elements.content: In order to evaluate the thermal stability of the title compound, a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. After an initial weight loss of approximately 3.8% within the temperature range of 40−100 °C, there was no further substantial weight change until a temperature of 220 °C, at which decomposition began. This result indicates that only a partial loss of the water molecules located within the porous channels occurred (calculated for 2.33 of the 4.33 equiv of water molecules per SBU: 3.9%). This can be probably attributed to the fact that the remaining 2 equiv of water molecules are retained through strong hydrogen-bonding interactions and/or O···Sn coordination bonds within the diorganotin carboxylate framework. That penta- and hexacoordinated diorganotin dicarboxylates can enhance their coordination number through coordination to water molecules has been shown previously. In order to examine if the crystal lattice does resist the partial elimination of guest molecules without collapsing, we heated part of the crystalline material for 1 h at 180 °C under a vacuum (approximately 10−2 Torr). The experiment showed that this thermal treatment did not destroy the crystallinity of the material, since the unit cell of the crystals remained unchanged (several crystals were examined).
cln_elements.clean_text: In order to evaluate the thermal stability of the title compound, a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. After an initial weight loss of approximately 3.8% within the temperature range of 40-100 °C, there was no further substantial weight change until a temperature of 220 °C, at which decomposition began. This result indicates that only a partial loss of the water molecules located within the porous channels occurred (calculated for 2.33 of the 4.33 equiv of water molecules per SBU: 3.9%). This can be probably attributed to the fact that the remaining 2 equiv of water molecules are retained through strong hydrogen-bonding interactions and/or O⋅⋅⋅Sn coordination bonds within the diorganotin carboxylate framework. That penta- and hexacoordinated diorganotin dicarboxylates can enhance their coordination number through coordination to water molecules has been shown previously. In order to examine if the crystal lattice does resist the partial elimination of guest molecules without collapsing, we heated part of the crystalline material for 1 h at 180 °C under a vacuum (approximately 10-2 Torr). The experiment showed that this thermal treatment did not destroy the crystallinity of the material, since the unit cell of the crystals remained unchanged (several crystals were examined).

metadata.title:
Bis(tetraorganodistannoxanes) as Secondary Building Block Units (SBUs) for the Generation of Porous Materials − A Three-Dimensional Honeycomb Architecture Containing Adamantane-type Water Clusters
Communications
